fields.Categories: Housing, Food, Pets, Health and safety, Resources for certain groups, Financial assistance, Replace documents, Insurance, Rebuilding your house, Employment

fields.Description: Get monthly benefits from the California Women, Infants and Children (WIC) program. Use these benefits to buy food for yourself and your children. You can also get nutrition and breastfeeding support.
fields.Service_name: WIC food benefits for women and children

fields.Description: CalFresh can help your family get access to healthy food. You can use monthly CalFresh benefits at most grocery stores and even farmers markets.
Find locations near you where you can get free food and groceries.

fields.Category description: Animal shelters, resources for lost pets

fields.Description: Get help if you lost a pet, had to leave a pet behind, or need shelter for your pet.
fields.Entity: California Department of Food and Agriculture

fields.Category description: Mental health, prescriptions, air and water safety, cleanup safety

fields.Description: Get the prescriptions you need through the Emergency Prescription Assistance Program.
fields.Entity: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

fields.Description: Check your air quality through the South Coast Air Quality Monitoring District.
fields.Entity: South Coast Air Quality Monitoring District

fields.Description: Contact crisis hotlines to get immediate mental health support.
Find digital mental health programs and support for youth, young adults, and families.
fields.Entity: California Health and Human Services Agency

fields.Description: FEMA housing assistance can include rental assistance and hotel or other short-term lodging reimbursement. Each disaster has its own deadline to apply, so check the website to see if you can still apply for help and check your status anytime.
Find a current list of open emergency shelters available for communities impacted by a disaster.
fields.Entity: California Governor's Office of Emergency Services

fields.Description: Resources that can help you find emergency shelter.

fields.Category description: Case management, help for certain groups

fields.Description: Find information and guides to disaster assistance for immigrant Californians. Available in Spanish, simplified Chinese, traditional Chinese, and Armenian.
Work with a case manager from Catholic Charities of California who can guide you through the recovery process.
Find CalVet information and resources for veterans and their families affected by the Los Angeles wildfires.

fields.Category description: FEMA, disaster loans, mortgage, renter, loan protections, taxes

fields.Description: FEMA can help support your recovery from a major disaster. You can apply at DisasterAssistance.gov and check your status anytime. Each disaster has its own deadline to apply, so check the website to see if you can still apply for help.

If you've already received the maximum amount of FEMA disaster assistance, you may be eligible for a grant from California's State Supplemental Grant Program (SSGP). FEMA will automatically apply on your behalf. You don't need to apply directly for these state disaster grants.
Learn about the extended deadline to file and pay 2024-2025 Los Angeles County income tax. The new deadline is October 15, 2025.

Learn about the extended deadline to file and pay 2025 Los Angeles County property taxes. The state property tax deadline is also extended. The new deadline is April 10, 2026. For those impacted by the LA fires, Governor Newsom has suspended penalties and interest on late property tax payments.
Get property tax relief if your home was damaged or destroyed.
Learn about disaster relief protections to help with your energy, natural gas, water, landline, and mobile phone bills.
If a disaster has damaged your home or personal property, you might be able to get financial assistance from the Small Business Administration. You do not need to own a business to apply.
fields.Service_name: SBA disaster loans for homeowners and renters

fields.Description: Homeowners may receive up to $20,000 for three months of mortgage payments for homes destroyed in recent disasters, including the 2025 Los Angeles County fires.
Find tips and resources to help you with 2024-2025 Los Angeles County fire victim insurance claims and issues.
fields.Service_name: Insurance tips and resources for wildfire claims

fields.Description: Learn about the state law that prevents insurance companies from canceling or not renewing home insurance policies for one year after a wildfire. And find out if your zip code is protected.
Get help filing an insurance claim or resolving an issue with a claim you already filed.
If you have CalVet home insurance, learn how to file a claim.

fields.Category description: Contractor search tools, debris removal, tree removal

fields.Description: Unlicensed contractors often prey on survivors of disasters. To protect yourself, request the contractor's license number and verify the status.
Find a professional licensed contractor. Each record lists the business name, address, a license status as expired, suspended, or revoked.
File a change of address.
If you work in fire cleanup or debris removal, learn about safety gear and employee protections.
fields.Service_name: Safety information for fire cleanup workers

fields.Description: See the major steps to take when rebuilding your home. This includes insurance claims, permits, hiring contractors and more.

All property owners who did not opt in for free government debris removal needed to obtain a Fire Debris Removal (FDR) permit and hire a licensed contractor by June 1, 2025. Fire debris must be removed by June 30, 2025.
During debris removal, the Army Corps will remove trees they decide are hazardous. But you can submit a waiver to ask them not to remove specific trees on your property.
fields.New Description: discuss: the link does not take people to information that is about the waiver. This may be a better link: https://recovery.lacounty.gov/debris-removal-2/phase-2/#1741114841068-ad25e7fc-fe3e

fields.Category description: Driver's licenses, IDs, birth, death, marriage records, property records

fields.Description: Replace California driver's licenses or ID Cards. Fees may be waived.
Replace titles for vehicles registered in California. Fees may be waived.
Replace manufactured and mobile home registration and titling documents. Fees may be waived.
fields.Entity: California Department of Housing and Community Development

fields.Description: Replace personal tax documents. File critical changes of information such as change of address and power of attorney.
fields.New Description: note: lets review together <airtable:mention id="menYIdVoJ2H1NfGLC">@christina florente</airtable:mention> . The link has nothing to do with replacing tax documents.
fields.Service_name: Personal income tax documents and info

fields.Description: Learn how to replace service records (DD 214), awards, and medals.
Replace Disabled Person Parking Placard.
Replace license plates and registration stickers.
Request vehicle or driver's records.
Learn how to get replacement birth certificates. The replacements are free, but youll need to go in person to a notary and pay a notary fee. Find forms in English and Spanish.
fields.New Description: note: changes dependent on new process

fields.Description: Learn how to get replacement marriage certificates. The replacements are free, but youll need to go in person to a notary and pay a notary fee. Find forms in English and Spanish.
fields.New Description: note: changes dependent on new process

fields.Description: Learn how to get replacement death certificates. The replacements are free, but youll need to go in person to a notary and pay a notary fee. Find forms in English and Spanish.
fields.New Description: note: changes dependent on new process

fields.Description: If you lost your job, apply for unemployment benefits.
If you are sick or injured as a result of a disaster, you may be eligible for disability benefits.
If you need time off work to care for your family, apply for Paid Family Leave.
Find job search tools like CalJOBS and other resources to help you find employment.
General support, referrals, and training to find a new job in California.
Apply for a new job on CalJOBS, Californias online job exchange system.
If you own a cleanup, debris removal, or rebuilding business, learn about worker safety laws and regulations. Find out how to protect your employees and keep your workplace safe.
fields.Service_name: Worker safety laws for cleanup and rebuilding

fields.Description: If your property was damaged in the January 2025 wildfires, you had until April 15, 2025 to sign up for free debris cleanup from the government. If you did not sign up or said no, you were required to get a Fire Debris Removal (FDR) permit and hire a licensed contractor to clean up your property by June 30, 2025.
fields.Service_name: 2025 wildfire debris removal for commercial properties

fields.Description: The deadline to apply for loans to repair physical damage to your business was March 31, 2025. You can still apply by October 15, 2025, for a loan to cover economic losses.

Get relief from penalties, collection costs, and interest if you have been directly affected by disasters declared as state of emergencies, both within California and nationally. You can also get up to a 3-month filing extension on your tax returns.
fields.Entity: California Department of Tax and Fee Administration
fields.Service_name: Business use tax or fee extension and relief

fields.Description: Learn about the extended deadline to file and pay business income tax in Los Angeles County. The new deadline is October 15, 2025.
Get an extension of up to two months to file state payroll reports and deposit state payroll taxes, without penalty or interest.
fields.Mail:
Employment Development Department
PO Box 826880
Sacramento, CA 94280-0001
fields.Service_name: Employer payroll tax and reporting extension

fields.Description: Find resources and support for businesses and workers impacted by the LA wildfires. This includes financial help, recovery programs, and workforce support.
fields.Entity: California Office of the Small Business Advocate
